Recent articles Video: Building a tool to copy-paste share terminal sessions using Claude Code for web - 23rd October 2025 Dane Stuckey (OpenAI CISO) on prompt injection risks for ChatGPT Atlas - 22nd October 2025 Living dangerously with Claude - 22nd October 2025.

item.title: Easy RISC-V: An interactive introduction to RISC-V assembly programming
item.description:
Others will look like they have some pattern to it. Congratulations, you’ve run your first RISC-V assembly program. If there’s a problem with your code, it will tell you about it and the emulator will not start.

Read more

item.title: Study finds growing social circles may fuel polarization
item.description:
The paradox: More connection, more division Are these two developments related. Do more close friends—and thus denser social networks—lead to network fragmentation and ultimately societal polarization. "When people are more connected with each other, they encounter different opinions more frequently.

Read more

item.title: Creating an all-weather driver
item.description:
and globally, we're applying the same systematic, scientific approach that enabled us to validate the Waymo Driver for these conditions to advance our capabilities for snowier, winter weather. Designing Generalizable SolutionsAt Waymo, we're building one autonomous system that works across diverse conditions—the same Waymo Driver navigating foggy San Francisco can navigate snowy Denver. Winter weather is complex, but we're committed to providing reliable service when riders need it most.

Read more

item.title: The new calculus of AI-based coding
item.description:
I've always been an efficient coder, finding time to write code even in limited amount of time I've been able to dedicate to coding over the past few years. Even with good testing and engineering practices, bugs occasionally make it through. As an example, I've always liked "wind tunnel" style tests, that test fully assembled system in a controlled environment.

Read more

item.title: It's not always DNS
item.description:
DNS failures are often the first observable problem because it’s one of the first things that needs to be done. This would happen no matter how you distribute the updated name to IP mappings. This, too, would happen no matter how you distribute the name to IP mappings.

Read more
